title: A Phase 1, Non-Randomized, Open-Label, Single-Dose Study To Evaluate The Pharmacokinetics, Safety, And Tolerability Of Dimebon [PF 01913539] In Subjects With Severely-Impaired And Normal Renal Function
description_brief: This study is to compare the pharmacokinetics of Dimebon in subjects with severe renal impairment to subjects with normal renal function after oral administration of a single oral 20-mg dose of Dimebon. This study is also to assess the safety and tolerability of a single oral 20-mg dose of Dimebon in subjects with severe renal impairment and subjects with normal renal function.
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is Dimebon (latrepirdine/PF-01913539), a small‑molecule repurposed antihistamine that was investigated for improving cognition/neuroprotection in Alzheimer’s disease rather than as a biologic targeting specific AD pathology (amyloid or tau). This places it conceptually as a cognitive enhancer under the provided definitions. citeturn0search7turn0search6

Mechanistic studies and reviews describe unclear/pleiotropic mechanisms (neurotransmitter modulation, mitochondrial effects, autophagy) and observed cognitive effects in some trials, rather than a clear disease‑pathology (amyloid/tau) targeting mechanism. citeturn0search7turn0search0turn0search4turn0search8

explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational agent is Dimebon (latrepirdine; PF‑01913539), a small‑molecule repurposed Russian antihistamine that has been reported to act on multiple systems — low‑affinity NMDA/receptor actions, modulation of various neurotransmitter systems, mitochondrial effects and induction of autophagy — i.e., a pleiotropic/unclear single‑pathway mechanism rather than a focused anti‑amyloid or anti‑tau therapeutic. citeturn0search4turn0search7turn0search3

Act: Key trial details and program context — Phase 1 single‑dose PK/safety study in subjects with severe vs normal renal function; drug identity confirmed as latrepirdine = Dimebon = PF‑01913539; earlier clinical development showed an apparently positive Phase II but failed Phase III results — support that the agent was pursued as a cognitive enhancer/neuroprotective small molecule rather than a targeted anti‑amyloid/tau biologic. citeturn0search1turn0search4

Reflect: Given the multiple reported mechanisms and the historical characterization of dimebon as a multitarget cognitive enhancer (with effects reported on autophagy, mitochondria, neurotransmission and receptor activity), the most appropriate CADRO classification is R) Multi‑target rather than a single‑mechanism CADRO category (e.g., A or B or D). This aligns with preclinical and clinical literature describing dimebon’s pleiotropic/uncertain mechanism. citeturn0search2turn0search7
